applications.notes: Remember to mention my research with Prof. Smith.

essays.prompt: What is the most significant challenge that society faces today?* (50)
How did you spend your last two summers?* (50)
What field of study appeals to you the most right now? (Note: Applicants select from a drop-down list.) Tell us more about why this field of study at MIT appeals to you. (100 words or fewer)

To be a Rutgers University–New Brunswick Honors College Scholar is to explore, learn, and engage at the highest level. If this describes you, we invite you to examine our website and then apply here: In 500 words, tell us how you have challenged yourself to embrace new experiences, continue learning about yourself and the world, and how you will use those actions and experiences to enhance the Rutgers Honors College community.* (500)
essays.text:
To avoid steep go-kart prices, my friend and I decided, why not try to make one? Our cheap welder and amateur skills resulted in some questionable welds and a floor made of a piece of sheet metal that rattled with a noise rivaling marching bands. In fact, the vibration was unscrewing the bolts. After our first fix failed, we added some grommets, and the bolts stayed tight. Building this go-kart has taught me something; I am not afraid to fail. That is how problems are identified and solved.

This learned process of finding problems is also how I learned my most important language. My most important community consists of just two people: my little brother Ryan and me. Ryan has a rare neurological condition and can’t speak, so I’ve learned to be his translator. For years, the incessant two-tone beep of his feeding pump was background noise. But I read Ryan’s reactions: the slight wince at the beep, the annoyance from being tethered for hours. I could see he was telling us it was a bad design.

Being his interpreter meant I needed to be his advocate. There had to be something better. My research led me to Bolus feeding with a syringe: it was faster, had fewer points of failure, and was silent. The solution wasn’t actually hard to find; the hard part was that we had all learned to stop looking for one. We had accepted that incessant beep as a fact of life. I brought it up to my parents, and with the approval of my brother’s doctors, we made the change. The silence was immediate, but the real proof was Ryan’s smile. My brother taught me that being empathic isn’t only passive; it’s a reason to take initiative.

I took my experiences to new academic areas. My experience at SAMS proved I was ready for a highly academic environment. There, I got my first chance to step into that world. In my polymer chemistry lab, I was given the vocabulary for my past failures. The brittle plastic on my robots, the shoddy welds on the go-kart, were pieces of chemistry and materials science. SAMS taught me that my hands-on background isn't a negative; it can be a foundation for building deeper learning.

After the whiteboard has been filled with ambitious ideas and the excitement is palpable, I like to ask my robotics team this: So, what’s the first step? My experiences taught me to be a self-starter. I know the difference between just imagining something and taking the first step to make it real, and how easy it is to start dreaming. In the Honors College Forum, as we tackle complex challenges, I will be the voice that turns shared ambition into that first, practical step. In the Rutgers Honors College, I will bring the hands-on persistence from the go-kart, the empathy from fixing the two-tone beep, and the practical leadership to help the community turn its vision into reality by pushing for that first step.

essays.prompt:
We all contribute to, and are influenced by, the communities that are meaningful to us. Share how you’ve been shaped by one of the communities you belong to.

Define community in the way that is most meaningful to you. This community example can be drawn from your family, school, workplace, activities or interests, or any other group you belong to. (350)
essays.text:
My most important community consists of just two people: my little brother Ryan and me. We have our own language, one that I’ve learned not from books, but from years of observation. Ryan has a rare neurological condition, and he can’t speak. So, I’ve taken up the role of his translator. A darting of his eyes means discomfort; his head swiveling and a smile when I call his name, excitement. 

For instance, I know that the quick jolt he makes while strapped in his chair isn’t just a symptom of his condition. He is saying, I feel stuck, and want to move.

This fluency proved critical when considering his medical equipment. To my parents and me, the difficult setup and incessant two-tone beep of Ryan’s feeding pump had become background noise. But I could read Ryan’s reactions: the slight wince at the piercing beep, the annoyance from being tethered to a chair for hours, unable to play or crawl around freely. Though we had tuned it out, he was telling us it was bad design.

Being his interpreter meant I needed to be his advocate. There had to be something better. My research led me to Bolus feeding with a syringe: it was faster, had fewer points of failure, and was silent. I brought it up to my parents, and with the approval of his doctors, we made the change. 

It was a strange feeling realizing the beep was no longer in the background. The silence was immediate. But the real proof of success was Ryan’s smile–he was happier, more present. The silence made our home feel calmer.

My community of two has shown me that observation isn’t the end. Empathy isn’t only a passive feeling; it is a reason to do something. It’s taught me to spot bad design–the two-tone beeps that we’ve learned to tune out–and try to fix it, especially for those who don’t have a voice to point it out.

history.text:
My most important community consists of just two people: my little brother Ryan and me. We have our own language, one that I’ve learned not from books, but from years of observation. Ryan has a rare neurological condition, and he can’t speak. So, I’ve taken up the role of his translator. A darting of his eyes means discomfort; his head swiveling and a smile when I call his name, excitement. My fluency is built on empathy.

For instance, I know that the quick jolt he makes while strapped in his chair isn’t just a symptom of his condition. He is saying I feel stuck, and want to move.

This fluency proved critical when considering his medical equipment. To my parents and me, the difficult setup and incessant two-tone beep of Ryan’s feeding pump had become background noise. But I could read Ryan’s reactions: the slight wince at the piercing beep, the annoyance from being tethered to a chair for hours, unable to play or crawl around freely. Though we had tuned it out, he was telling us it was bad design.

Being his interpreter meant I needed to be his advocate. There had to be something better. My research led me to Bolus feeding with a syringe. It was faster, had fewer points of failure, and was silent. I brought it up to my parents. With the approval of his doctors, we made the change. 

It was a strange feeling realizing the beep was no longer in the background. The silence was immediate. But the real proof of success was Ryan’s smile–he was happier, more present. The silence made our home feel calmer.

My community of two has fundamentally shaped me. It has taught me that observation isn’t enough. Empathy isn’t only a passive feeling; it is a springboard, compelling me to act on my understanding and advocate for a world that fits better, especially for those who don’t have a voice.

essays.prompt:
All engineering applicants are required to write two long essays and four short essays.. The first two essays have a 200 word limit each while the remaining two have a 100 word limit each. 

Fundamentally, engineering is the application of math, science, and technology to solve complex problems. Why do you want to study engineering?* (200)
essays.text:
With only two hands, I had a truly impossible dilemma: my dog's big-eyed begs for fetch or my homework. Since commercial launchers only work with balls and Teddy is devoted to his floppy penguin plushie, I invented another option. Using a 3D printer and an Arduino, I created The Launcher from gears and motors. Toss a toy in, and it’d take off.

But in my excitement, I’d forgotten–I designed for the penguin, not the dog. Teddy just stared, confused. He’d nudge the penguin, waiting for me to throw it, not understanding that he had to drop the toy inside. I still had to drop it in myself and interrupt my work.

Though he loved the launch, it was a failure: he didn’t know how to use it. Searching for solutions, I discovered human-robot interaction; and I realized engineering isn’t just making something work, it’s making it work for someone. I want to study control systems to make the motion approachable, and materials science to design parts soft enough for Teddy, but strong enough for the launch. That’s the engineering I want to pursue: a mix of physics and thoughtfulness that turns parts into something a person (or dog!) can use.

history.text:
With only two hands, I had a truly impossible dilemma: my dog's big-eyed begs for fetch or my homework. Since commercial launchers only work with balls and Teddy is devoted to his floppy penguin plushie, I invented another option. Using a 3D printer and an Arduino, I created The Launcher from gears and motors. Toss a toy in, and it’d take off.

But in my excitement, I’d forgotten–I designed for the penguin, not the dog. Teddy just stared, confused. He’d nudge the penguin, waiting for me to throw it, not understanding that he had to drop the toy inside. I still had to drop it in myself and interrupt my work.

Though he loved the launch, it was a failure: he didn’t know how to use it. Searching for solutions, I discovered Human (or dog!) Robot Interaction, realizing engineering isn’t just making something work; it’s making it work for someone. I want to study control systems to make the motion approachable and material science to choose materials soft enough for Teddy, but strong enough for the launch. That’s the engineering I want to pursue: a mix of physics and thoughtfulness that turns parts into something that fits into a life.

essays.prompt: Why do you think you would love to study at Cornell Engineering?* (200)
essays.text:
I want to be a human-centered engineer, and Cornell Engineering’s deeply interdisciplinary approach is the perfect way to pursue this philosophy. Building for my family has shown me that technical success is ineffective if not user-centered.

By majoring in mechanical engineering and taking human-centered design courses from the College of Human Ecology, like Applied Ergonomic Methods, I will have the technical foundation to solve problems and the human-centered knowledge to identify them first. At Cornell, I want to take the passion for robots I've built over four years in my high school club to the Human-Robot Collaboration & Companionship Lab under Professor Guy Hoffman, where I will put my love for robots and human-centered thinking towards integrating technology and people. 

Outside the lab, I’m eager to bring my hands-on skills from projects like my amateur go-kart to the Cornell Maker Club, where I’ll learn and share with people who love tinkering as much as I do. More importantly, I want to join the Cornell Assistive Technologies project team, as it embodies the mindset that Cornell’s Design Tech initiative perfectly captures: “Technology is fundamentally human.” This is where I will put my belief into practice: designing for people, not just for function.

history.text:
I want to be a human-centered engineer, and Cornell Engineering’s deeply interdisciplinary approach is the perfect way to pursue this philosophy. Building for my family has shown me that technical success is ineffective if not user-centered.

By majoring in mechanical engineering and taking human-centered design courses from the College of Human Ecology, like Applied Ergonomic Methods, I will have the technical foundation to solve problems and the human-centered knowledge to identify them first. Having spent 4 years making robots with my club, my passion for robots is concrete. At Cornell, I want to join the Human-Robot Collaboration & Companionship Lab under Professor Guy Hoffman, where I will put my love for robots and human-centered thinking towards integrating technology and people. 

Outside the lab, I’m eager to bring my hands-on skills from projects like my amateur go-kart to the Cornell Maker Club–where I can learn and share with people who love tinkering as much as I do. More importantly, I want to join the Cornell Assistive Technologies project team, as it embodies the mindset that Cornell’s Design Tech initiative perfectly captures. “Technology is fundamentally human.” This is where I will put my belief into practice: designing for people, not just for function.

essays.prompt: What brings you joy?* (100)
essays.text: My friend and I love racing, but those go-kart prices are hard to stomach. So we came up with a silly idea: why not try to make one? Soon, we were cursing the sparks burning our hands through the glove’s mesh holes. Our cheap welder and amateur skills resulted in some questionable welds. The floor? A piece of sheet metal that rattles with noise rivaling marching bands. The steering? Well… Still figuring that out. But the joy is in the process. If it's making a new, terrifying noise, I’m probably about to learn something important–and laugh while I’m at it.

history.text: My friend and I love racing, but those go-kart prices are hard to stomach. So we came up with a silly idea: why not try and make one? We cursed the sparks burning our hands through the glove’s mesh holes. Our cheap welder and amateur skills resulted in some questionable welds. The floor? A piece of sheet metal that rattles with noise rivaling marching bands. The steering? Well… Still figuring that out. But the joy is in the process. If it's making a new, terrifying noise, I’m probably about to learn something important–and laugh while doing it.

essays.prompt: What do you believe you will contribute to the Cornell Engineering community beyond what you've already detailed in your application? What unique voice will you bring? * (100)
essays.text: After the whiteboard has been filled with ambitious ideas and the excitement is palpable, I like to ask my robotics team this: So, what’s the first step? With my parents too busy to help me, I had to create my own starting points, from simple homework to my projects. Because of this, I know how it feels to be stuck dreaming, and the difference between just imagining something and taking the first step to make it real. That’s the voice I’ll bring to Cornell. I will turn shared ambition into the first, practical step that makes an idea a reality.

history.text: After the whiteboard has been filled with ambitious ideas and the excitement is palpable, I like to ask my robotics team this: So, what’s the first step? With my parents too busy to help me, I had to create my own starting point, from simple homework to my projects. Because of that, I know the paralyzing feeling of dreaming, and the difference between just imagining it and taking the first step to make it real. That’s the voice I will bring to Cornell. I will turn shared ambition into the first step that gets the ball rolling.

essays.prompt: What is one activity, club, team, organization, work/volunteer experience or family responsibility that is especially meaningful to you? Please briefly tell us about its significance for you.* (100)
essays.text: When I chose to help seniors with their devices, the job seemed to be strictly transactional. But what I found is that the exchange is never that simple. Once, I helped with something small: uploading an SD card of photos to the cloud. “I haven’t seen these pictures since 2010,” she said, and suddenly, I was hearing the stories of her vacation behind them. This activity is meaningful to me because the transaction is always reversed. I come to offer a little technical help, and in return, I get to listen to the stories that technology has unlocked.

essays.prompt: What is one award you have received or achievement you have attained that has meant the most to you? Please briefly describe its importance to you.* (100)
essays.text: As a first-generation, low-income student, I wasn’t sure that I could handle a highly academic environment. Earning a place at SAMS, I got my first chance to step into that world. Living there for six weeks, I took classes on topics I’ve never heard of, interacted with professors and students, and was able to hold my own with peers from across the nation. The certificate was nice and shiny, but the most important achievement was that I felt like I belonged. That summer, I gained the confidence to aim for a place like Cornell.

history.text: Being a first-gen, low-income student, I wasn’t sure that I could handle a highly academic environment. Earning a place at SAMS, I got my first chance to step into that world. Living there for six weeks, I took classes on topics I’ve never heard of, interacted with professors and students, and was able to hold my own with peers from across the nation. The certificate was nice and shiny, but the most important achievement was that I felt like I belonged. That summer, I gained the confidence to aim for a place like Cornell.

essays.prompt: How will opportunities at Purdue support your interests, both in and out of the classroom? (Respond in 250 words or fewer.)* (250)
essays.text:
Purdue has the ideal environment for me to develop my philosophy of human-centered engineering. Academically, I plan to take the Design and Innovation minor, where I’ll take courses like TECH 34000 - Prototyping Technology For People, to provide a formal framework for the user factors I’ve explored in my personal projects. After spending four years making robots in my high school club, I know I like robots, which is why I was excited to see the CoMMA Lab at Purdue. I can put my love for robotics into a setting that integrates humanity and technology through its Human-Robot Collaboration focus. 

At heart, I am a builder, and I love to experiment with new ideas. Purdue’s Bechtel Innovation Design Center is perfect for me. There, I will be able to collaborate with people who love to tinker as much as I do, and receive formal guidance on ways to turn my ideas into reality. My experience building things for others has made me wonder what is possible with robots working alongside us, which is why I’d like to join the Humanoid Robot Club and contribute to its ambitious goals. Furthermore, my work creating a program to help seniors with their devices taught me that I often learn more than I teach, a dynamic I hope to continue through EPICS. At Purdue, I will not only build better machines but also become a better, more thoughtful engineer.

essays.prompt: Briefly discuss your reasons for choosing your major and your interest in studying at this campus location (Indianapolis or West Lafayette). (Respond in 250 words or fewer.)* (250)
essays.text:
I’d like to study Multidisciplinary Engineering in the Visual Design Track because of my dog. With only two hands, I had a truly impossible dilemma: my dog's big-eyed begs for fetch or my homework. Since commercial launchers only work with balls and Teddy is devoted to his floppy penguin plushie, I invented another option. Using a 3D printer and an Arduino, I created The Launcher from gears and motors. Toss a toy in, and it’d take off. But my dog had no idea how to use it. I still had to interrupt my work and place it in myself. 

In building this, I realized that the functionality of my invention was irrelevant if it couldn’t be used. That’s the engineering I want to pursue: a mix of physics and thoughtfulness that turns parts into something a person (or dog!) can use.

This is why I am so drawn to Purdue’s Visual Design Engineering. It is one of the only programs I’ve found that treats form and function as a single challenge. It gives me the background to bridge human factors, aesthetic design, and robust mechanical principles into one field of study. 

I am choosing the West Lafayette campus because a program so interdisciplinary thrives on proximity. To really bridge human factors and robust mechanical principles, I need to be surrounded by the core engineering labs, makerspaces like the Bechtel Center, and a high concentration of students and faculty from all disciplines. West Lafayette is where those cross-disciplinary interactions happen.

essays.prompt: 1. Explain your vision, ideas, or goals for how you hope to shape your honors experience while at Purdue. Please put this in the context of the four pillars which are the foundation of the John Martinson Honors College. (500 word maximum)* (500)

2. Please describe the interdisciplinary nature of your chosen field of study and how it complements or supports other fields. (Examples: You might describe how your work in a liberal arts career may impact or inform the work of an engineer.) (500 word maximum)* (500)

Explain, in detail, an experience you've had in the past 3 to 4 years related to your first-choice major. This can be an experience from an extracurricular activity, in a class you’ve taken, or through something else.* (150)
Describe your personal and/or career goals after graduating from UIUC and how your selected first-choice major will help you achieve them.* (150)

At the University of Michigan, we are focused on developing leaders and citizens who will challenge the present and enrich the future. In your essay, share with us how you are prepared to contribute to these goals. This could include the people, places, experiences or aspirations that have shaped your journey and future plans.* (300)

Describe the unique qualities that attract you to the specific undergraduate College or School (including preferred admission and dual degree programs) to which you are applying at the University of Michigan. How would that curriculum support your interests?* (550)
Why do you want to study your chosen major and why do you want to study your major at Georgia Tech?* (300)

The Honors College develops leaders who are engaged members of their community and profession. How have you been of service to your community (either as a volunteer or in a work environment) and what has that taught you about being a leader? How will you contribute to the Honors community? How might the selection of your Honors track align with your skills? See our website for additional information honors.njit.edu.* (300)
We know you lead a busy life, full of activities, many of which are required of you. Tell us about something you do simply for the pleasure of it. (150 words or fewer)

While some reach their goals following well-trodden paths, others blaze their own trails achieving the unexpected. In what ways have you done something different than what was expected in your educational journey? (225 words or fewer)

MIT brings people with diverse backgrounds together to collaborate, from tackling the world’s biggest challenges to lending a helping hand. Describe one way you have collaborated with others to learn from them, with them, or contribute to your community together. (225 words or fewer)
How did you manage a situation or challenge that you didn’t expect? What did you learn from it? (225 word or fewer)

List a selection of texts, resources and outlets that have contributed to your intellectual development outside of academic courses, including but not limited to books, journals, websites, podcasts, essays, plays, presentations, videos, museums and other content that you enjoy. (100 words or fewer)*

Tell us about an aspect of your life so far or your lived experience that is important to you, and describe how it has shaped the way you would learn from and contribute to Columbia's multidimensional and collaborative environment. (150 words or fewer)*

At Columbia, students representing a wide range of perspectives are invited to live and learn together. In such a community, questions and debates naturally arise. Please describe a time when you did not agree with someone and discuss how you engaged with them and what you took away from the interaction. (150 words or fewer) *

In college/university, students are often challenged in ways that they could not anticipate. Please describe a situation in which you have navigated through adversity and discuss how you changed as a result. (150 words or fewer)*
Why are you interested in attending Columbia University? We encourage you to consider the aspect(s) that you find unique and compelling about Columbia. (150 words or fewer)*
What attracts you to your preferred areas of study at Columbia Engineering? (150 words or fewer)*

Princeton values community and encourages students, faculty, staff and leadership to engage in respectful conversations that can expand their perspectives and challenge their ideas and beliefs. As a prospective member of this community, reflect on how your lived experiences will impact the conversations you will have in the classroom, the dining hall or other campus spaces. What lessons have you learned in life thus far? What will your classmates learn from you? In short, how has your lived experience shaped you? (500 words or fewer)*
Princeton has a longstanding commitment to understanding our responsibility to society through service and civic engagement. How does your own story intersect with these ideals? (250 words or fewer)*
What is a new skill you would like to learn in college?* (50)
What brings you joy? * (50)
What song represents the soundtrack of your life at this moment?* (50)

We want to be sure we’re considering your application in the context of your personal experiences: What aspects of your background (your identity, your school setting, your community, your household, etc.) have most shaped how you see yourself engaging in Northwestern’s community, be it academically, extracurricularly, culturally, politically, socially, or otherwise? (fewer than 300 words)*

We encourage you to answer at least one and no more than two of the following questions. Please respond in fewer than 200 words per question:


1)  Painting “The Rock” is a tradition at Northwestern that invites all forms of expression—students promote campus events or extracurricular groups, support social or activist causes, show their Wildcat spirit (what we call “Purple Pride”), celebrate their culture, and more. What would you paint on The Rock, and why?


2)  Northwestern fosters a distinctively interdisciplinary culture. We believe discovery and innovation thrive at the intersection of diverse ideas, perspectives, and academic interests. Within this setting, if you could dream up an undergraduate class, research project, or creative effort (a start-up, a design prototype, a performance, etc.), what would it be? Who might be some ideal classmates or collaborators?


3) Community and belonging matter at Northwestern. Tell us about one or more communities, networks, or student groups you see yourself connecting with on campus.


4)  Northwestern’s location is special: on the shore of Lake Michigan, steps from downtown Evanston, just a few miles from Chicago. What aspects of our location are most compelling to you, and why?


5)  Northwestern is a place where people with diverse backgrounds from all over the world can study, live, and talk with one another. This range of experiences and viewpoints immeasurably enriches learning. How might your individual background contribute to this diversity of perspectives in Northwestern’s classrooms and around our campus?

Over the past 150 years, every monumental discovery at Hopkins has started with a first step: The first draft by a Pulitzer Prize-winning author. A prototype that led to a life-changing medical invention. The first pitch that launched a new startup venture. As we commemorate the university's sesquicentennial—150 years since its founding—we continue to celebrate first steps just as much as final achievements. Tell us about an important first in your life—big or small—that has shaped you. (350 word limit)*
What historical moment or event do you wish you could have witnessed?* (50)
Briefly elaborate on one of your extracurricular activities, a job you hold, or responsibilities you have for your family.* (50)
List five things that are important to you.* (50)
The Stanford community is deeply curious and driven to learn in and out of the classroom. Reflect on an idea or experience that makes you genuinely excited about learning.* (250)

Virtually all of Stanford's undergraduates live on campus. Write a note to your future roommate that reveals something about you or that will help your roommate – and us – get to know you better.* (250)
Please describe what aspects of your life experiences, interests and character would help you make a distinctive contribution as an undergraduate to Stanford University.* (250)

Write a short thank-you note to someone you have not yet thanked and would like to acknowledge. (We encourage you to share this note with that person, if possible, and reflect on the experience!) (150-200 words)*
How will you explore community at Penn? Consider how Penn will help shape your perspective, and how your experiences and perspective will help shape Penn. (150-200 words)*

Penn Engineering prepares its students to become leaders in technology by combining a strong foundation in the natural sciences and mathematics with depth of study in focused disciplinary majors. Please share how you plan to pursue your engineering interests at Penn, particularly within the intended major you selected. (150-200 words)

To help inform your response, applicants are encouraged to learn more about Penn Engineering and its mission to prepare students for global leadership in technology. This information will help you develop a stronger understanding of academic pathways within Penn Engineering and how they align with your goals and interests.*

We are looking for students who want to be bridge builders—students who can connect people, groups, and ideas to span divides, foster understanding, and promote collaboration within a dynamic, interconnected, and vibrant global academic community. We are eager for you to tell us how your experiences have helped you understand what qualities and efforts are needed to bridge divides so that people can better learn and work together.

Please consider one or more of the following questions in your essay:
·      Tell us about a time you encountered a perspective different from your own. What did you learn—about yourself, the other person, or the world?
·      Tell us about an experience you've had working with others who have different backgrounds or perspectives. What challenges did your group face? Did you overcome them, and if so, how? What role did you try to play in helping people to work together, and what did you learn from your efforts?
·      Tell us about someone you've observed who does a particularly good job helping people think or work together. How does this person set the stage for common exploration or work? How do they react when difficulties or dissensions arise? (250)
Most students choose their intended major or area of study based on a passion or inspiration that’s developed over time – what passion or inspiration led you to choose this area of study? (300)

Many students pursue college for a specific degree, career opportunity or personal goal. Whichever it may be, learning will be critical to achieve your ultimate goal. As you think ahead to the process of learning during your college years, how will you define a successful college experience? (300)

Consider your application as a whole. What do you personally want to emphasize about your application for the admission committee’s consideration? Highlight something that’s important to you or something you haven’t had a chance to share. Tell us, don’t show us (no websites please). (300)
Please explain why you wish to study in the academic areas you selected above.* (150)
Based upon your exploration of Rice University, what elements of the Rice experience appeal to you?* (150)

Rice is strengthened by its diverse community of learning and discovery that produces leaders and change agents across the spectrum of human endeavor. What perspectives shaped by your background, experiences, upbringing, and/or cultural identity inspire you to join our community of change agents at Rice? (500)
